section.title: Setting the Page Size
section.p: If you do not set the size, uses portrait US-LETTER with margins of 1in.
You can also specify the page orientation, using the portrait or landscape keywords.
You can use multiple times the @page rule, the properties will merge as in ordinary CSS element styling rules.

section.title: Using Page Selectors to Style the Blank, Left, Right, First and Last Pages
section.p: There are cases in which you need to have different page settings depending on the position of the page in the printed material.
The :first selector is used to style the the first page from a sequence of pages.
The :blank selector is used to sytle the blank pages that appear as a result of forced page breaks.

section.title: Using Named Pages
section.p: In the examples above, we changed the default page settings.

Let's consider that we need to put one of our document table elements on a landscape page. We define a named page: table-landscape-page, that switches the orientation to landscape. To maximize the space available to the table, this page has a smaller margin. The A4 size defined by the default @page rule is inherited by the named page.
